bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A prohibited act is a tort actionable without proof of damage,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by any person against whom the prohibited act was directed, or

if the prohibited act was directed against a class of persons, by any member of
            that class.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
If a corporation or society engages in a prohibited act, every director or officer
          of the corporation or society who authorized, permitted or acquiesced in the commission of
          the prohibited act may be sued by the persons referred to in subsection (1) and is liable in the
          same manner as the corporation or society.

In an action brought under this section, the commission of a prohibited act by any
          director or officer of a corporation or society must be presumed, unless the contrary is
          shown, to be done, authorized or concurred in by the corporation or society.
An action under this section must be commenced in the Supreme Court.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Attorney General may intervene in action

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
The Attorney General may intervene in an action commenced under
          section 2.

If the Attorney General intervenes, the Attorney General becomes a party to the
          proceedings.

If a person commences an action under section 2, the person must serve the
          Attorney General with a copy of the notice of civil claim within 30 days after commencing
          the action.

A party to an action brought under section 2 may be awarded damages or exemplary
          damages.

If the court awards damages or exemplary damages in an action brought by a member
          of a class of persons under section 2, the court may order payment of the damages to any
          person, organization or society that, in the court's opinion, represents the interests of
          the class of persons.

In an action brought under section 2, the court may, in addition to any other
          relief, grant an injunction.

A person who engages in a prohibited act commits an offence and is liable to a
          fine of not more than $2 000 or to imprisonment for not more than 6 months, or to
          both.

A corporation or society that commits an offence under subsection (1)
          is liable to a fine of not more than $10 000.

If a corporation or society commits an offence under subsection (1), every director or
          officer of the corporation or society who authorized, permitted or acquiesced in the
          commission of the prohibited act commits an offence and is liable to the penalties under
            subsection
            (1).
